title: Ab Initio Derived Force Fields for Predicting CO
Adsorption and Accessibility of Metal Sites in the Metal–Organic Frameworks M-MOF-74 (M = Mn, Co, Ni, Cu)
abstract: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are versatile nanoporous materials that have gained significant interest as low heat capacity, high selectivity sorbents for CO

capture applications. Large-scale atomistic simulations for identifying high-performance MOFs are possible, but are limited to systems for which existing molecular mechanics force fields describe the interactions between the guest and framework atoms with sufficient accuracy. However, standard force fields are not applicable to cases involving coordinatively unsaturated metal centers that can strongly bind specific sorbate molecules. It has been previously shown that improved force fields can be derived from quantum mechanical calculations. In this work, we derived force fields for an isostructural series of MOFs, M-MOF-74, where M = Mn, Co, Ni, and Cu, from first principles. Monte Carlo calculations in the Gibbs ensemble were used to calculate the CO

adsorption isotherms in order to assess the quality of the derived force field parameters and to determine a generally applicable procedure for obtaining a reliable force field for a targeted MOF and adsorbate system. The computed CO
adsorption isotherms for the different M-MOF-74 members agree with experimental measurements at low loading and show that Ni-MOF-74 possesses the highest affinity toward CO

and Cu-MOF-74 the weakest. In addition, we explored the source of open metal site and pore inaccessibility in these materials and quantified its impact on adsorption, especially the discrepancies often observed between experiments and simulations at high loadings.

and an even greater number have been computationally predicted.

One way to carry out this separation is through absorption in aqueous alkanolamine solutions.

This process suffers from many limitations, most notably the large energy demands for alkanolamine recovery stemming from the high heat capacity of water. MOFs, having a much lower heat capacity, could become an energy efficient alternative. This trait alone is not enough to warrant the use of MOFs. Other traits, such as thermal stability,

Given the large number of potential materials that could be examined and the time and cost involved in performing the required experiments, integrating computer simulations and experiments offers an attractive solution. The CO
adsorption performance of many synthesized MOFs, hypothetical MOFs, and zeolites have been probed through large-scale, high-throughput computational studies.

To reduce the computational cost, these studies are performed using molecular simulations with effective molecular mechanics force fields. Although capable of identifying potentially high-performance materials, the results of these studies are limited by the quality of the force fields used. This is a greater problem for MOFs than zeolites, because MOFs are significantly more chemically diverse, which is why generic force fields such as the universal force field (UFF)
provide inconsistent results for these materials.

One unique property of MOFs, which is relevant to the application of carbon capture, is that a significant fraction of these frameworks contain unsaturated metal sites. These electron deficient metal atoms can act as strong yet often reversible binding sites of small guest species such as CO
. An example of a series of MOFs containing open metal sites is M

(dobdc), also known as M-MOF-74 or CPO-27-M (where dobdc denotes the 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligand that carries a formal charge of −4). A series of analogues have been synthesized using various metals which exhibit differences in their CO
M-MOF-74 is comprised of hexagonal, one-dimensional pores that are lined with M
ions whose open coordination sites point directly into the channel. This topology has one of the highest open metal site densities known. CO

interactions with open metal sites in MOFs are often poorly modeled by existing generic molecular mechanics force fields, which stipulates that parameters need to be optimized to correctly describe the unique environments present within these MOFs.

There are only a limited number of experimental isotherms throughout the literature, and they often lack reproducibility due to the differences in sample handling and preparation. Parametrization of force fields for adsorption in MOFs from first-principles calculations is therefore preferable.
There has been a series of studies that developed force fields for adsorption of various gases in MOFs which have been summarized recently in a review article by Fang  et al.
and one by Odoh et al.
have developed a force field capable of predicting CO
adsorption in Mg-MOF-74 from Møller–Plesset second-order perturbation theory (MP2) calculations. In a subsequent work, Borycz et al.
have used a similar approach to predict CO
adsorption in Fe-MOF-74. Chen et al.
have also successfully derived a force field for the adsorption of CO
by using a dispersion-corrected double-hybrid functional (B2PLYP-D2).
In this work we examined four isoreticular M-MOF-74 analogues, where M = Mn,
and developed force fields for CO
adsorption in these systems. To our knowledge, no force field parametrization for CO
adsorption in these MOF-74 analogues has been reported in the literature. Based on previous work,
we used quantum chemical calculations on cluster models of M-MOF-74 to obtain force field parameters for the metal–CO

interaction that takes place within the series. In addition, we explored the use of density functional theory (DFT) with two different functionals along with a dispersion correction as an alternative to wave function theory at the MP2 level for the computation of the relevant potential energy curves (PECs). We were able to obtain force fields that yield excellent agreement with experiments for all four materials at low loading. Note that UFF grossly underestimates the isotherms for three out of the four materials (Mn-, Co-, and Ni-MOF-74). At higher pressures, we observe a systematic overestimation for all of the materials, as previously reported for other analogues.

This deviation between predicted and experimentally measured isotherms in M-MOF-74 at higher pressure has been typically attributed to the inaccessibility of the pores due to either crystal defects or incomplete activation,

i.e., remaining tightly bound solvent molecules. In this work, we examined these two hypotheses by modeling adsorption in the presence of residual solvent molecules as well as blocked pore regions and have quantified the extent of the pore inaccessibility in each of these materials.
